title: White House, Congress Struggle to Find Common Ground on Gun Legislation
text:
WASHINGTON—Lawmakers remained divided on Tuesday over a legislative path to reduce mass shootings, with Republicans looking to the White House for guidance and Democrats pledging to press ahead with their own measures.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) emphasized that he would only take up gun legislation that he knew President Trump would sign.

“I’m going to wait and assess the proposal that actually could become law,” Mr. McConnell told reporters, declining to go into specifics on what he would support.

In the Democratic-controlled House, the Judiciary Committee debated three gun-related bills as lawmakers in the chamber urged the Senate to take action immediately.

At the White House, Trump administration officials met with Republican members of Congress in a closed-door lunch to discuss gun-policy options. The meeting was the first such gathering in Washington since mass shootings in California, Texas and Ohio left dozens of people dead over the past several weeks, though Mr. Trump spoke with several lawmakers over the August recess.

Mr. Trump has previously voiced support for legislation expanding background checks for gun purchases, but he hasn’t endorsed specific policy proposals. Lawmakers and White House officials remain skeptical that significant gun-control legislation can win congressional approval ahead of the 2020 election.

“He basically said contribute whatever ideas,” Sen. James Lankford (R., Okla.) said of Mr. Trump’s guidance from the meeting. “The president’s going to be able to continue to look at it.”

Aides plan to brief Mr. Trump this week on his legislative and policy options on guns, said a person familiar with internal conversations. The White House has received ideas and proposals from agencies, lawmakers and outside groups.

Topics that White House officials have discussed include improving background checks, removing guns temporarily from people considered dangerous—sometimes called red-flag laws—enhancing public-safety funding and subjecting mass shooters to expedited capital punishment.

White House officials have also said they are considering the use of the National Instant Criminal Background Check System to alert state law-enforcement officials when a person prohibited from purchasing a firearm tries to buy a gun.

A Washington Post-ABC poll published Monday showed that 86% of Americans support implementing red-flag laws and that 89% favor expanding federal background checks. The poll found a majority of support for both measures among Republicans, white evangelical Christians, members of gun-owning households and other conservative groups.

Activists calling for Congress to pass gun-control legislation gathered outside the Capitol Hill on Tuesday, holding signs. One said “Voters are watching.”

Mayors from around the country who have faced shootings in their areas of jurisdiction also met with Mr. McConnell to urge him to bring legislation requiring background checks for all gun purchases.

Congressional Republicans are looking to the White House for leadership on gun measures—and political cover from Mr. Trump over what would likely be a tough vote for many GOP lawmakers regardless of what policy the president endorses.

“Whatever position he decides to adopt is very important to a lot of our members,” said Sen. John Thune (R., S.D.) of the president’s position.

Some Republicans, such as Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, have indicated support for red-flag laws. Mr. Graham and Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D., Conn.) have proposed a federal grant program to help law enforcement work with mental-health professionals to remove guns from people deemed dangerous. Other Republicans are concerned over how such proposals would address gun owners’ due process.

“I appreciate the White House’s point of view, whatever it ends up being,” said Sen. John Kennedy (R., La.) “I’m sure it is going to be persuasive, but for me, it’s not going to be dispositive.”

Current law allows unlicensed sellers to sell firearms at gun shows, online or elsewhere without a federal dealer’s license or a background check on the buyer. An estimated 22% of U.S. gun owners acquired their most recent firearm without a background check, according to a 2017 survey published in the Annals of Internal Medicine. Legislation passed by the House in February would require background checks for all gun purchases.

The Democratic-led House has encouraged the Senate to take up the background-checks bill and has made it clear that Democratic lawmakers plan to pursue more gun-related legislation without waiting for the president’s endorsement.

The House Judiciary Committee is looking at legislation to ban high-capacity magazines and at two bills that would prevent gun ownership by those deemed a risk of hurting themselves or others, and for people convicted of misdemeanor hate crimes.

Democrats are worried that if they take the spotlight off the summer’s mass shootings, their chance to pass significant legislation will fade as public attention diminishes.

“This whole town is Groundhog Day, until it’s not, until something changes,” said Sen. Chris Murphy (D., Conn.). “We may be being set up for another Groundhog Day experience in the next one or two weeks but I’m not ready to concede that.”
